Belgia
1591 8 Au
g
To my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: Au
g
May it please yo
r
good L. there is nothing more und
r
stood
of
e ennemyes
ceeding
, th
e
t
w
ch
I writ in my last from
e Haghe. That some
te of his forces are passed
e Maese
the rest as yet remayning about
Vendlo
&
Ruremonde
The
Duke
himself w
th
some com
p
of horse & foote is gon to
e Spa, having left
Verdugo
to c
o
mand in his absence.
The forces of this countrey ly c
o
tinually in
e Betuwe
between
Wagening
e
&
Rhen
e
& do not intend to passe
e
Wael, till they see
t
e ennemy is furder removed. It doth
appeare by c
r
taine l
re
s w
ch
wee have newly intercepted
that
e ennemy is much moved w
th
his late losses in thes
countreys & conceaveth litel hope of his happy succes in
this sommers exploit
. There is one father Holt an
English Jesuit in theyr camp, unto whom there were l
re
s
addressed in english not conteyning any matter that is
greatly worth
e knowing, but yet discovering some fugitives
& theyr p
nt
intent to come for england. I have sent heerinclosed
the original l
re
s. I am demanded at this p
nt
by
e
Councel of state
what her
Ma
ty
hath resolved in
e affaires
of
Ostend.
for
M
r
Caron
doth c
r
tify that her Hig
nes
intention hath bin signified unto mee, & that I have bin
required to deal w
th
e states that Commissaries may be chosen on
both sides, for a final redresse of all theyr griefes. But as
yet I had no l
re
to any such effect neith
r
fr
o
her Ma
ty
nor fr
o
yo
r
L. nor any at all at any time since
e 18 of
June. Howbeit as in s
v
ral oth
r
l
re
s I have writen to yo
r
L. it is greatly behoofull
t
some such order should bee
taken, & that verie speedely for the states of
Zeland
have
written flatly to
e Councel, theyr l
re
bearing date
e 2 of
this moneth, that forasmuch as they have not heth
r
too
vided
for
e reformation of those abuses of
e
Governo
r
of Ostend
they th
e
selves will seek some remedy. But how theyr mening
is to deal I c
a
not yet advertise. Moreover I have bin
told that it hath bin sayd by some spetiall
sons of
e
states assembly at
e Hage, that except
e governo
r
will
relent & keepe w
th
in
e bound
of his commission fr
o
e contrey
they will tolerate no longer & declare him rebel. And so
I do assure my self, as I have alwaies signified in
my l
re
s to yo
r
L. that they will rather proceed to termes
fol.192v
To my L.
Treasurer
Au
g
8
1591
Belgia: 1591: Au
g
of hostility then be bridled by
e Governo
r
in
e administration of
theyr goverment. Wherin her ma
t
s
vice is avantaged
now by these endevo
rs
of
e Governo
r
, more th
e
otherwise yt
might be by an ordinary meanes w
th
e countrys approbation
or les discontentment, I cannot conjecture of my self, & truly
as hethertoo I have bin privy to nothing by
e Governo
rs
information. I do
test unto yo
r
L. I do not affect
in mine owne regard to know any
thing
kinde of matter
that is not properly
tinent to
e place, where I am trusted
w
ch
I hold to be sufficient to keep mee busye in my charges.
Nevertheles I finde yt very requesit in affa i res of any moment
that no innovation should bee made, by Governo
r
or other of her
Ma
t
ministers but yt should bee first im
ted & so practised or
not practised w
th
effectual correspondence, w
th
whosoever shalbee
here to reside in Councel for her Hig
nes
. for otherwise, bee yt
said w
th
submission to yo
r
L. correction, howsoev
r
they are led
w
th
apparance of good courses, they may fall very easily
into many mistaking
, & such great inconveniences, as may p
r
judice
her Ma
ty
& these countreys very highly. w
ch
I signifye thus
boldly, provoked th
r
unto through
e great desire
at
I have
to acquit my duty to her Ma
ty
w
th
unfayned
s
vice, & through
my wounted c
o
fidence, that yo
r
L. will accept my speaking
cleerly in such causes.
And so I take &c.
Arnham. Au
g
8 1591
